clusters.title: Trump reiterates threat to sue BBC over speech edit: ‘You can’t allow people to do that’ – latest updates
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Threatens to Sue BBC Over Speech Edit

items.title: Trump reiterates threat to sue BBC over speech edit: ‘You can’t allow people to do that’ – latest updates
items.standfirst: US president claims broadcaster has ‘defrauded the public’ and he has an ‘obligation’ to take legal actionResponding to UK culture secretary Lisa Nandy’s refusal to review the BBC board membership of Robbie Gibb, Liberal Democrat culture, media and sports spokesperson Anna Sabine said on Tuesday evening:This is the wrong choice by Lisa Nandy. Robbie Gibb isn’t fit to serve on the BBC board, and the BBC charter gives the government the power to sack him. I hope the prime minister will step in and do the right thing. Continue reading...
items.content: US president claims broadcaster has ‘defrauded the public’ and he has an ‘obligation’ to take legal actionResponding to UK culture secretary Lisa Nandy’s refusal to review the BBC board membership of Robbie Gibb, Liberal Democrat culture, media and sports spokesperson Anna Sabine said on Tuesday evening:This is the wrong choice by Lisa Nandy. Robbie Gibb isn’t fit to serve on the BBC board, and the BBC charter gives the government the power to sack him. I hope the prime minister will step in and do the right thing. Continue reading...

items.title: Donald Trump says he has ‘obligation’ to sue BBC over speech edit
items.standfirst: US president sets Friday deadline for corporation to respond to billion-dollar legal threatTrump to sue BBC – latest updatesDonald Trump has said he feels he has “an obligation” to sue the BBC over its editing of one of his speeches, as a deadline looms for the corporation to respond to his billion-dollar legal threat.The US president accused the broadcaster of having “defrauded the public” with an edition of Panorama last year that spliced together two parts of a speech he made on 6 January 2021 and has given it until Friday to respond. Continue reading...
items.content: US president sets Friday deadline for corporation to respond to billion-dollar legal threatTrump to sue BBC – latest updatesDonald Trump has said he feels he has “an obligation” to sue the BBC over its editing of one of his speeches, as a deadline looms for the corporation to respond to his billion-dollar legal threat.The US president accused the broadcaster of having “defrauded the public” with an edition of Panorama last year that spliced together two parts of a speech he made on 6 January 2021 and has given it until Friday to respond. Continue reading...

items.title: Would Trump’s $1bn lawsuit against the BBC hold up in court?
items.standfirst: The US president would find it difficult to prove defamation if he sues in the US, where free speech is safeguarded.
items.content: The US president would find it difficult to prove defamation if he sues in the US, where free speech is safeguarded.

items.title: Trump threatens BBC with $1 billion defamation case over speech edit
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump said he had an "obligation" to sue the BBC for defamation in an interview released on Tuesday, after the broadcasting company aired a documentary splicing together two parts of a speech made by Trump. Here's a look at how legal action between the US President and the world's biggest broadcaster could play out.
items.content: US President Donald Trump said he had an "obligation" to sue the BBC for defamation in an interview released on Tuesday, after the broadcasting company aired a documentary splicing together two parts of a speech made by Trump. Here's a look at how legal action between the US President and the world's biggest broadcaster could play out.

items.title: Trump says he has 'obligation' to sue BBC over speech edit
items.standfirst: The US president indicates he will go ahead with a lawsuit against the BBC over how his speech was presented by Panorama.
items.content: The US president indicates he will go ahead with a lawsuit against the BBC over how his speech was presented by Panorama.

items.title: Trump threatens to sue BBC for $1 billion over January 6 speech edit
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump has threatened to sue the BBC for $1 billion, alleging that the British public broadcaster attempted to “interfere in the presidential election” last year by editing his January 6th speech. NBC News’ Raf Sanchez has the details, as two top executives have already resigned amid mounting pressure on the organization.
items.content: President Donald Trump has threatened to sue the BBC for $1 billion, alleging that the British public broadcaster attempted to “interfere in the presidential election” last year by editing his January 6th speech. NBC News’ Raf Sanchez has the details, as two top executives have already resigned amid mounting pressure on the organization.

ai_summary: Trump claims the BBC "defrauded the public" with an edited speech segment.
He is giving the BBC a deadline to respond to a billion-dollar legal threat.
The speech edit spliced together parts of a speech from January 6, 2021.
Some question the likelihood of a defamation case succeeding in the US.
Others are critical of the BBC board member Robbie Gibb.

items.title: Ukraine suspends justice minister for alleged link to $100m corruption case
items.standfirst: Justice Minister German Galushchenko allegedly took part in the scheme involving state nuclear power firm Energoatom.
items.content: Justice Minister German Galushchenko allegedly took part in the scheme involving state nuclear power firm Energoatom.

items.title: Ukraine suspends justice minister amid energy corruption probe
items.standfirst: The Ukrainian government has suspended Justice Minister German Galushchenko as part of an ongoing investigation into corruption in the energy sector. Anti-corruption prosecutors have charged seven individuals, including Timur Mindich, a close ally of President Volodymyr Zelensky, accused of orchestrating a $100 million corruption scheme. Liza Kaminov and Laurent Berstecher report.
items.content: The Ukrainian government has suspended Justice Minister German Galushchenko as part of an ongoing investigation into corruption in the energy sector. Anti-corruption prosecutors have charged seven individuals, including Timur Mindich, a close ally of President Volodymyr Zelensky, accused of orchestrating a $100 million corruption scheme. Liza Kaminov and Laurent Berstecher report.

items.title: Top ally of Ukraine's president accused of $100 million graft scandal
items.standfirst: Ukrainian investigators on Tuesday accused Timur Mindich, a close ally and longtime business associate of President Volodymyr Zelensky, of orchestrating a $100 million corruption scheme in the energy sector. The scandal has escalated a major standoff over graft in the war-torn country.
items.content: Ukrainian investigators on Tuesday accused Timur Mindich, a close ally and longtime business associate of President Volodymyr Zelensky, of orchestrating a $100 million corruption scheme in the energy sector. The scandal has escalated a major standoff over graft in the war-torn country.

items.title: Ukraine’s energy sector faces wide-scale investigation over ‘kickback’ allegations
items.standfirst: Anti-corruption agency says state nuclear power operator Energoatom taking illicit payments of 10-15%Ukraine’s anti-corruption bureau said on Monday that it was conducting a large-scale investigation into the country’s energy sector, alleging kickbacks in transactions involving the state nuclear power operator, Energoatom.The bureau, which operates independently of the government, alleged that several senior figures were involved. Ukrainian media identified one of them as Timur Mindich, a businessman and associate of Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy. Continue reading...
items.content: Anti-corruption agency says state nuclear power operator Energoatom taking illicit payments of 10-15%Ukraine’s anti-corruption bureau said on Monday that it was conducting a large-scale investigation into the country’s energy sector, alleging kickbacks in transactions involving the state nuclear power operator, Energoatom.The bureau, which operates independently of the government, alleged that several senior figures were involved. Ukrainian media identified one of them as Timur Mindich, a businessman and associate of Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Ukraine suspended Justice Minister German Galushchenko due to corruption allegations.
The investigation involves a $100 million corruption scheme in the energy sector.
Seven individuals, including a close ally of Zelensky, are charged.
The anti-corruption agency is investigating kickbacks involving Energoatom.
The prime minister said the decision was made at an emergency government session.

clusters.title: US aircraft carrier arrives in Latin America, escalating Venezuela tensions

items.title: US aircraft carrier arrives in Latin America, escalating Venezuela tensions
items.standfirst: The US has deployed its largest warship, the USS Gerald R. Ford, to the Latin America region, escalating tensions with Venezuela. Washington says the move targets drug trafficking, while President Maduro calls it an attempt to oust him from power.
items.content: The US has deployed its largest warship, the USS Gerald R. Ford, to the Latin America region, escalating tensions with Venezuela. Washington says the move targets drug trafficking, while President Maduro calls it an attempt to oust him from power.

items.title: Largest U.S. aircraft carrier arrives in Latin America
items.standfirst: The U.S. Navy’s largest carrier has arrived in Latin America as a show of force and part of President Trump’s war on drug cartels. NBC News’ Richard Engel is in Colombia.
items.content: The U.S. Navy’s largest carrier has arrived in Latin America as a show of force and part of President Trump’s war on drug cartels. NBC News’ Richard Engel is in Colombia.

items.title: Pentagon’s largest warship enters Latin American waters as US tensions with Venezuela rise
items.standfirst: USS Gerald R Ford’s arrival marks the largest US military presence in the region since the invasion of Panama in 1989The US navy has announced that the USS Gerald R Ford, regarded as the world’s newest and largest aircraft carrier, has entered the area of responsibility of the US Southern Command, which covers Latin America and the Caribbean.The deployment of the ship and the strike group it leads – which includes dozens of aircraft and destroyer ships – had been announced nearly three weeks ago, and its arrival marks an escalation in the military buildup between the US and Venezuela. Continue reading...
items.content: USS Gerald R Ford’s arrival marks the largest US military presence in the region since the invasion of Panama in 1989The US navy has announced that the USS Gerald R Ford, regarded as the world’s newest and largest aircraft carrier, has entered the area of responsibility of the US Southern Command, which covers Latin America and the Caribbean.The deployment of the ship and the strike group it leads – which includes dozens of aircraft and destroyer ships – had been announced nearly three weeks ago, and its arrival marks an escalation in the military buildup between the US and Venezuela. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The US deployed the USS Gerald R. Ford to Latin America.
The US says the move targets drug trafficking.
Venezuela's President Maduro calls it an attempt to oust him.
The deployment marks the largest US military presence since 1989.
Colombia halted intelligence sharing with the US.

items.title: Pakistan Taliban claim responsibility for deadly terror attack in Islamabad
items.standfirst: Defence minister says country is in ‘state of war’ after suicide blast kills 12 and injures 27 outside court buildingsAt least 12 people have been killed in a suicide blast in Islamabad carried out by the Pakistan Taliban, as the country’s defence minister said a deadly surge in terror attacks had put the country in a “state of war”.The explosion, which was confirmed as a suicide attack by several government ministers, took place outside district court buildings in the capital on Tuesday at about 12.30pm. The area is usually heavily crowded with lawyers and litigants attending trials. Continue reading...
items.content: Defence minister says country is in ‘state of war’ after suicide blast kills 12 and injures 27 outside court buildingsAt least 12 people have been killed in a suicide blast in Islamabad carried out by the Pakistan Taliban, as the country’s defence minister said a deadly surge in terror attacks had put the country in a “state of war”.The explosion, which was confirmed as a suicide attack by several government ministers, took place outside district court buildings in the capital on Tuesday at about 12.30pm. The area is usually heavily crowded with lawyers and litigants attending trials. Continue reading...

items.content: At least 12 people have been killed in a suicide bombing outside the gates of a court in Pakistan's capital of Islamabad, the country's interior minister has said.

Pakistan's defense minister said the country is in a "state of war."
The bomber was unable to enter the court complex.

items.title: US supreme court extends Trump pause on $4bn in food aid benefits
items.standfirst: More uncertainty after justices allow temporary block on full payments for Snap, relied upon by 42 million AmericansMillions of Americans grappling with food insecurity will face more uncertainty this week after the US supreme court enabled the Trump administration to continue withholding funds for food stamps.In an administrative stay issued on Tuesday, the highest court upheld the administration’s request to extend a pause on a federal judge’s ruling that would have required $4bn in funding for the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program or Snap, the food aid relied on by 42 million people, to be distributed. The funding freeze has been given two additional days, and will now remain in place until midnight on Thursday. Continue reading...
items.content: More uncertainty after justices allow temporary block on full payments for Snap, relied upon by 42 million AmericansMillions of Americans grappling with food insecurity will face more uncertainty this week after the US supreme court enabled the Trump administration to continue withholding funds for food stamps.In an administrative stay issued on Tuesday, the highest court upheld the administration’s request to extend a pause on a federal judge’s ruling that would have required $4bn in funding for the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program or Snap, the food aid relied on by 42 million people, to be distributed. The funding freeze has been given two additional days, and will now remain in place until midnight on Thursday. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The Supreme Court extended a pause on SNAP benefit payments.
The pause blocks payments for food stamps.
The funding freeze will last until Thursday.
The court upheld the administration's request.
The program is relied upon by 42 million Americans.

items.standfirst: Taiwan said it is assessing the possibility of using chip export controls in its diplomatic efforts, a sign it has not completely abandoned a tool that it briefly threatened to deploy against South Africa.
items.content: Taiwan said it is assessing the possibility of using chip export controls in its diplomatic efforts, a sign it has not completely abandoned a tool that it briefly threatened to deploy against South Africa.

Taiwan is a major player in the global semiconductor industry.

items.title: China removes two popular gay dating apps from Apple and Android stores
items.standfirst: Withdrawal of Blued and Finka raises fears of further crackdowns on LGBT rights amid growing restrictionsTwo of China’s most popular gay dating apps have disappeared from app stores in the country, raising fears of a further crackdown on LGBT communities.As of Tuesday, Blued and Finka were unavailable on Apple’s app store and several Android platforms. Users who had already downloaded the apps appeared to still be able to use them. Continue reading...
items.content: Withdrawal of Blued and Finka raises fears of further crackdowns on LGBT rights amid growing restrictionsTwo of China’s most popular gay dating apps have disappeared from app stores in the country, raising fears of a further crackdown on LGBT communities.As of Tuesday, Blued and Finka were unavailable on Apple’s app store and several Android platforms. Users who had already downloaded the apps appeared to still be able to use them. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Two popular gay dating apps, Blued and Finka, were removed from app stores in China.
Apple confirmed the removal following an order from Chinese authorities.
The removals raise concerns about potential crackdowns on LGBT rights.
Users who had already downloaded the apps may still be able to use them.
The apps' removal occurred on both Apple and several Android platforms.

clusters.title: Google denies removing Maps border between Western Sahara and Morocco
clusters.neutral_headline: Google denies removing Maps border between Western Sahara and Morocco

items.title: Google denies removing Maps border between Western Sahara and Morocco
items.standfirst: Google on Tuesday denied removing the borderline between the Western Sahara and Morocco on its Maps application, saying that the line had never been visible for Moroccan users. The Western Sahara is a disputed, mineral-rich territory largely controlled by Morocco but claimed by the pro-independence Polisario Front.
items.content: Google on Tuesday denied removing the borderline between the Western Sahara and Morocco on its Maps application, saying that the line had never been visible for Moroccan users. The Western Sahara is a disputed, mineral-rich territory largely controlled by Morocco but claimed by the pro-independence Polisario Front.

items.title: Borderline ambiguity: How Google Maps removes disputed Western Sahara border for Morocco users
items.standfirst: The tech giant has released a statement acknowledging the use of different border displays between Western Sahara and MoroccoThe dotted lines illustrating the border between Western Sahara and Morocco, indicating the former’s disputed territory status, have never been visible to people using Google Maps in the latter.After media reports last week highlighted the discrepancy, tying it to the UN security council endorsing the Moroccan autonomy plan for Western Sahara, the tech company released a statement acknowledging it has always displayed the border differently depending on the search region. Continue reading...
items.content: The tech giant has released a statement acknowledging the use of different border displays between Western Sahara and MoroccoThe dotted lines illustrating the border between Western Sahara and Morocco, indicating the former’s disputed territory status, have never been visible to people using Google Maps in the latter.After media reports last week highlighted the discrepancy, tying it to the UN security council endorsing the Moroccan autonomy plan for Western Sahara, the tech company released a statement acknowledging it has always displayed the border differently depending on the search region. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Google denies removing the border between Western Sahara and Morocco on Maps.
The company stated the border line was never visible for Moroccan users.
The Western Sahara is a disputed territory claimed by the Polisario Front.
Google acknowledged different border displays based on search region.
The discrepancy was highlighted after reports about the UN's endorsement.

clusters.title: TikTok influencer killed in public ‘execution’ as Mali’s jihadist crisis worsens
clusters.neutral_headline: TikTok influencer killed in public ‘execution’ as Mali’s jihadist crisis worsens

items.title: TikTok influencer killed in public ‘execution’ as Mali’s jihadist crisis worsens
items.standfirst: Mariam Cissé, who posted videos in support of ruling junta, received death threats before being abducted and killedA TikTok influencer has been shot dead in front of a crowd by suspected jihadists in Mali, underlining how state control has been eroded in the west African nation.Mariam Cissé often wore combat attire to post videos in support of the country’s military to more than 100,000 followers on TikTok. According to Yehia Tandina, the mayor of Timbuktu region, she was abducted in a market on Friday by unknown gunmen. Continue reading...
items.content: Mariam Cissé, who posted videos in support of ruling junta, received death threats before being abducted and killedA TikTok influencer has been shot dead in front of a crowd by suspected jihadists in Mali, underlining how state control has been eroded in the west African nation.Mariam Cissé often wore combat attire to post videos in support of the country’s military to more than 100,000 followers on TikTok. According to Yehia Tandina, the mayor of Timbuktu region, she was abducted in a market on Friday by unknown gunmen. Continue reading...

items.title: TikTok influencer publicly executed in Mali
items.standfirst: Armed men in Mali have abducted and publicly executed a TikTok influencer who posted videos in support of the West African nation's military, local authorities have said.
items.content: Armed men in Mali have abducted and publicly executed a TikTok influencer who posted videos in support of the West African nation's military, local authorities have said.

ai_summary: A TikTok influencer was publicly executed in Mali by suspected jihadists.
The influencer, Mariam Cissé, supported the ruling junta in videos.
She received death threats before being abducted and killed.
The incident highlights the erosion of state control in Mali.
Cissé had over 100,000 followers on TikTok.
